arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Foundation for Child Development collection is arranged in six series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Foundation for Child Development had its origins in the Guild for the Crippled Children of the Poor of New York City (the Guild), an organization whose mission was to "care for the physical, social, domestic, educational, economic, and spiritual conditions of these unfortunates." It became the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children (AACC) in 1908, when it was established in New York City as a voluntary agency that sought to teach and aid disabled children who were victims of polio.

In the early twentieth century, physically disabled children were often homebound with no access to formal education. Mabel Irving Jones, a concerned citizen and advocate for these youngsters, provided the impetus behind the creation and eventual incorporation of an agency operating under the auspices of the New York City Children's Aid Society. By 1904 nearly 120 disabled school-aged children were attending school outside of the home; in 1906, Public School 104 of the New York City Board of Education operated the first public school class for crippled children. The Guild sought to treat those children neglected by hospitals and clinics and the "hundreds of chronic cases of crippled children whom these charities do not and cannot reach." The Guild cooperated with churches and other social services organizations including St. John's Guild, the Henrietta Industrial School, and the Hartley House Settlement, to teach children outside of the home, provide a luncheon meal, and return them to their homes. The Guild's second Annual Report in 1898 indicated that this is the "first systematic effort ever made in New York City to give the crippled children out of institutions a helpful education."

Separated from the Children's Aid Society in 1908, the AACC was supported entirely by contributions and employed a staff of ten, led by trained nurses. In addition to providing transportation to school and health clinics and braces and other therapeutic devices, the AACC also established physical rehabilitation facilities. By 1940, over 30,000 children had benefited from these services, including children with cerebral palsy and other disorders of fetal and neonatal origin.

The organization's early focus on the needs of a stranded school-aged population firmly defined its legacy. In later years, similar enterprises supported direct-care and research to benefit adult rehabilitation. The AACC joined with New York University-Bellevue Hospital to establish the Children's Division of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, today known as the Rusk Institute. During World War II, their pioneering work helped to rehabilitate injured soldiers.

In 1944, the AACC received an $11 million bequest from the Estate of Milo M. Belding, a silk manufacturer and banker whose donation honored his spouse, Annie K. Belding, a devoted volunteer and association board member for over twenty years. This bequest allowed the AACC to become a grant-making organization. Although the organization continued to provide direct services to children, in 1950 the Visiting Nurse Service of New York assumed this aspect of the agency's services. Also during this period, the Association expanded its purview to include within its programs the developmentally disabled, the emotionally disturbed, and children with genetically based disorders, including circulatory and metabolic disorders. In 1962, it formed the Committee on Belding Scholars, with the specific goal of encouraging research on problems that "lie between, or are germane to, both the biological and social sciences."

In 1972 the Association changed its name to the Foundation for Child Development (FCD) to reflect its role as a grant-making organization and in particular its evolved focus on child development. Included within its mission were goals of preventing child poverty and promoting the economic stability of families. The Foundation developed several new program areas; appointed Staff Scientists, enabling specialists in child development to pursue research while simultaneously contributing to the Foundation's mission; and, most particularly, awarded grants in areas that linked research to policy, program, and leadership development. During the mid-1970s grants focused upon methods that would transfer knowledge from scholarly endeavor to government policy-makers. The George Washington University, Vanderbilt University, and the University of California at Los Angeles benefited from this support. In 1976 the Foundation published the pioneering report on The State of the Child: New York City, by Trude Lash and Heidi Sigal. Revised regularly, the report examined the indicators that reveal changes in the conditions of children's lives. In 1977, the Foundation released the preliminary findings of the National Survey of Children, directed by Nicholas Zill. This report compiled nationwide findings of interview responses from more than 2,200 pre-teens, from the ages of 7-11, and more than 1,700 of their parents' responses. These ground-breaking survey results spoke of the attitudes, fears, and social temper of a generation.

In early 1972, Dr. Mary Jo Kline from the Columbia University Oral History Research Office conducted oral history interviews with eleven council members about the Foundation's development after World War II. The original intent was to undertake a complete history of the organization by combining portions of the interviews with information from the Foundation's archives, but this project was never completed.

By 1980, the Foundation's annual assets were approximately $30 million; annual grant expenditures were in the vicinity of $2 million. Around this time, the Foundation shifted focus to include examination of the causes of debilitating physical conditions and funded projects focused upon research, demonstration, and education. The formation in 1979 of Child Trends, Inc., which aimed "to improve the quality, scope and use of statistical information concerning children," reflected the FCD's expanded goals.

The Foundation for Child Development is a national private philanthropy dedicated to the principle that all families should have the social and material resources to raise their children to be healthy, educated, and productive members of their communities. The Foundation seeks to understand children, particularly the disadvantaged, and to promote their well-being. They believe that families, schools, nonprofit organizations, businesses, and government at all levels share complementary responsibilities in the critical task of raising new generations.

The Foundation sponsors basic and policy-relevant research about the factors that promote the optimal development of children and adolescents; policy analysis, advocacy, services, and public education to enhance the discussion and adoption of social policies that support families in their important child-raising responsibilities; and leadership development activities linked to the programmatic focus of the Foundation. The Foundation believes that by integrating these approaches, it will strengthen its effectiveness in achieving its mission.

This broad statement further demonstrates the Foundation's special interest in accommodating working families with children, who are struggling to meet their basic needs. Three themes mark Foundation support in the late twentieth century: linking research on children and families to form relevant programs and activities; isolating new approaches to devising social strategies for children and families; and increasing availability and access to early education programs and health care for children.

The Foundation hoped to compensate for the reduction in government-supported programs for children at risk by focusing more closely upon programs which would have a direct impact upon both children and families, with its research and action in this direction geared toward influencing public policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include Barbara Blum; Herbert G. Birch; Orville G. Brim, Jr.; Urie Bronfenbrenner; Hillary Rodham Clinton; Lewis B. Cuyler; Charles Dollard; Jessie Emmet; Nevil Ford; Alice FitzGerald; Charlayne Hunter Gault; George J. Hecht; Mavis Hetherington; Jerome Kagan; Sheila Kamerman; Trude Lash; Emily McFarland; Leonard Mayo; Evelyn Moore; Kathleen Mortimer; Emil Pattberg; Stephen A. Richardson; Mary French Rockefeller; Milton J. E. Senn; Heidi Sigal; Chester Swinyard; Ruby Takanishi; Ray Valdivieso; George Wheatley; and Nicholas Zill.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records are open for research. Access copies of microfilm are available onsite at RAC. Select digital PDF files are available online.

Audio cassette tapes of oral history interviews are closed to research. Conditions of access and duplication of oral history interviews are managed through Columbia University's Oral History Research Office.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The records of the Foundation for Child Development were transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center in 1998, 1999, and 2004.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection begins with microfilm reel 2.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in:

The Foundation for Child Development (Guild for Crippled Children of the Poor of New York City) records (RAC); The Leonard Mayo papers, at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities; the New York City Board of Education records, at Teachers College, Columbia University; the Russell Sage Foundation records (RAC); the Social Science Research Council records (RAC); and the William T. Grant Foundation records (RAC).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For records documenting the early administrative history of the Foundation for Child Development including its origins as the Guild for Crippled Children of the Poor of New York City and its later incarnation as the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children 1904-1914, 1919-1920, 1931-1933 please refer to the RAC copy of the Foundation for Child Development (Guild for Crippled Children of the Poor of New York City) records (FA405).

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged in two sub-subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains minutes of Council meetings for the period 1951-1992 and 1996.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Audio cassettes of interviews dated April 1994 with Emily McFarland, Kathleen Mortimer, and George M. Wheatley are found in Series 6, Audio-visual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains biographical information regarding Council members and their terms of involvement in the organization.

Oral history interviews were conducted with eleven members of the council, who served terms between 1951 and 1955. These interviews provide a perspective on the post-World War II Foundation and the development of the organization after the acceptance of the Belding funds. This historical information was intended to supplement the Foundation's narrative history written by Alice FitzGerald. This subseries includes the transcripts of interviews conducted with the following individuals: Dr. Herbert G. Birch and Stephen A. Richardson; Lewis B. Cuyler; Charles Dollard; Jessie K. Emmet; Alice FitzGerald; Emily F. McFarland; Leonard Mayo; and Milton J. E. Senn.
Transcripts do not exist for the oral history interviews of Kathleen Mortimer and George M. Wheatley.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Members of the Council records are not available for viewing online. Microfilm copies are available onsite at RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: President Barbara Blum directed the Foundation from 1986-1996. Prior to her tenure at FCD, she was involved in the planning of the Child Welfare Reform Act of 1979 and was Commissioner of Social Services of the State of New York during Governor Hugh Carey's term.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Numerous presentations on behalf of the Foundation are included in this material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Annual Reports of the FCD span one full century, from the inception of the organization known as the Guild for the Crippled Children of the Poor of New York City in 1898 through the late twentieth century. This series contains Annual Reports for the years 1898, 1902, 1904, 1907, 1909-1910, 1912-1934, 1946-1998. There is also a comprehensive report for the period 1900-1945.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Reprints are arranged alphabetically by the author's last name. When there are multiple authors, an asterisk immediately follows the grantee-author's name, and the reprint is filed alphabetically according to this name. Additional pamphlets concerning seminar proceedings and related scientific studies follow this alphabetical sequence. Pamphlets published by the Foundation for Child Development may also be listed under the Foundation's former name, the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children (AACC).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains scientific papers and pamphlets authored by grantees, officers, and consultants of the Foundation for Child Development. These materials have been retained in their original form and have not been microfilmed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abramson, Harold. "History of the Special Committee on Infant Mortality: A Blueprint of Planned Programs for Postgraduate Medical Education." "New York Medicine 27," no. 8, (August 1971): 298-303.
Abramson, Harold. "History of the Special Committee on Infant Mortality: A Blueprint of Planned Programs for Postgraduate Medical Education." "New York Medicine 27," no. 7, (July 1971): 272-280.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Paper presented at the annual meeting of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, New York, New York, 1956.
Beck, Bertram M. "The Lower East Side Family Union: A Social Invention." An Occasional Paper from the Foundation for Child Development, New York, New York, March 1979.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Child Trends, Inc. is a not-for-profit organization incorporated in New York State and devoted to "improving the quality, scope and use of statistical information concerning children; to foster collaboration among medical, behavioral and social scientists and other professionals in the advancement of multi-disciplinary and ecological approaches to the understanding of child health, learning, behavior and development, to improve the concepts and methods that guide research on the quality of children's lives and on the status and prospects of children in the United States; and to design and coordinate collaborative research projects in this field, to educate the public with respect to current trends in the circumstances of children's lives and to disseminate indicators of child health, learning, behavior and development, to support other organizations or persons with materials or services in furtherance of the above goals."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative material, surveys, and research reports ('Papers') are included in this subseries pertaining to trends in child behavior, surveys of the well-being of children, and trends in family dynamics.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: This separate allocation engaged a number of institutions to study "the ecological factors promoting or hindering healthy development to justify the recommendation of particular child-care policies and programs." A major consultant in this program was Dr. Urie Bronfenbrenner of Cornell University, who designed a research program to gather epidemiologic and demographic data to reveal the effect of ecological and environmental factors upon developmental health. The first policy study group met on October 3, 1972, to discuss the parameters of this research project; an Advisory Committee next met on March 14, 1973, to propose the adoption of Dr. Bronfenbrenner's approach and outline objectives and criteria for research proposals. Adopting a multi-institutional approach, the Advisory Committee reviewed proposals for endeavors of one to three years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The institutions selected for participation are individually documented in this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Public and private groups, and academic, religious, and other non-profit organizations supporting an improved quality of life for children through social science research, legal advocacy, and support services, are represented in this subseries. Although a number of 'local' New York City groups received support from the FCD, support was also extended to organizations throughout the United States.

Throughout this period, the Foundation sought to integrate the efforts of child-development scholars and those who affected public policy. Grants reflecting this interest include the Foundation's support for the Family Impact Seminar at George Washington University and for Vanderbilt University's Center for the Study of Families and Children.

Another recipient of Foundation support on behalf of children's advocacy was the Lower East Side Family Union in New York City, which provided community-based services to underprivileged children and families.
Grants for the Congressional Science Fellowships in Child Development are documented on reels 88, 89, and 90.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Two studies which were developed in New York City and carried out during the 1960s and 1970s concerning children and families were incorporated into the program known as "State of the Child: New York City I and II." Data was collected that focused upon children's health, involvement in school, and the family and communities in which they lived, with the intent of describing the quality of life of the over 2 million children living in New York City at that time and, particularly, those at risk. Using publicly distributed statistics, this pioneering effort to develop a measurable "State of the Child" included child-rearing, income distribution, and services provided by public and voluntary institutions. The emphasis was placed upon what was termed as "applied social indicators" to answer questions regarding the success of school reading programs, health services, children's safety during that time and in the decade or two prior to the study. Program "monitors" in place attempted to recommend improvements in services through monitoring, particularly the child health stations, public school attendance program, food programs in the public schools, and school bilingual programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The State of the Child reports and related memoranda are found on reels 99-100.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged in two sub-subseries:

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: This Foundation program supported research by "young scholars" on the "social and affective development of children." This program was to aid in the development of career goals for post-doctoral researchers in childhood development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applicants denied grant awards for the Young Scholars Program during 1983-1984 are alphabetically ordered in this subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Declination records are not available for viewing online. Microfilm copies are available onsite at RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Audio cassette tapes representing certain oral history interviews comprise this series.

Interviews were conducted with eleven members of the council, who served terms between 1951 and 1955. These interviews provide a perspective of the post-WWII Foundation and the development of the organization after the acceptance of the Belding funds. This historical information was intended to supplement the Foundation's narrative history written by Alice FitzGerald.
The taped interviews are with Emily McFarland, April 26-27, 1994 (2 cassette tapes); Kathleen Mortimer, April 14, 1994 (1 cassette tape); and George Wheatley, April 14, 1994 (1 cassette tape). There are also two reels of magnetic tape concerning the Foundation's Seventy-Fifth Anniversary, February 4, 1975, and its Annual Meeting, September 28, 1979.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, are available at the discretion of RAC. The oral history interviews on four audio cassettes are fragile and are not available for playback.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission is required to cite, quote from, or reproduce any portion of the Oral History interviews. For copyright information and permission, please contact the Columbia Center for Oral History, Columbia University.
